evidence.pdf_reference: as a cocatalyst. As mentioned, the bare CaZrO 3 photocatalyst shows the photocatalytic activity.The photoexcited electrons generated in the bulk can reach to the surface through the conduction band originating from 4dorbitals of Zr atoms, and would react with protons and CO 2 molecules at the surface Zr sites (eq. 1 and 2).The photogenerated holes can migrate through the balance band originating from 2p-orbitals of oxygen atoms, reacted to the surface oxygen anion sites, and react with water to produce

and react with water to produce oxygen and protons (eq.3).It is fact that the small amount of Ag species deposited on this CaZrO 3 did not function as a cocatalyst but decreased the photocatalytic activity.The amount of the Ag species would not be enough to form Ag nanoparticles of moderate size.It is suggested that most of these Ag species are present as positively charged Ag cations or small clusters (discussed later) on these surface active sites to change their properties.Especially, the oxygen

production rates.Anyway, the Ag species of around 4 wt would be the most available for the selective CO 2 reduction.These results suggest that the role of the loaded Ag species can be divided into at least two depending on the loading amount, i.e., the Ag species diminished the photocatalytic active sites on the CaZrO 3 crystal surface, while the Ag species provided by the moderate loading amount improved the photocatalytic activity especially for CO 2 reduction to produce CO as a cocatalyst. zirconate samples.Fig. 7 shows the formation rate of products and the CO selectivity in the photocatalytic reaction test with the Ag-loaded zirconate and titanate samples.The photocatalytic activity of each Ag-loaded zirconate sample was lower than that of the bare zirconate sample, while the Agloaded titanate samples showed higher CO production rate than the bare samples.In other words, although the addition of Ag species on titanate photocatalysts increased the photocatalytic activity for CO 2 reduction,

mixture in an aluminum crucible was once calcined at 1173 K for 6 h, ground, and calcined again at 1373 K for 12 h.The obtained CaTiO 3 , SrTiO 3 and BaTiO 3 samples are referred to as CTO, STO, and BTO. The generation condition of the extraction is given: If Light_source is Solar or Solar Simulator, Lamp is always Solar Simulator.

evidence.pdf_reference: EDX-8000 (Shimadzu), where the calibration curve was experimentally obtained from the samples prepared by the impregnation method. The photocatalytic reaction test was carried out in the inner-irradiation-type reactor with a 400 W high-pressure Hg lamp by using 0.5 g of the photocatalyst sample in an aqueous solution of NaHCO 3 (1.0M, 1500 mL).After the air was purged by a bubbling flow of CO 2 at a flow rate of 35 mL min -1 for 3 h in the dark, the photocatalytic reaction test was started upon

reactor.Then the suspension was magnetically stirred for 1 h with a bubbling flow of Ar gas to remove air, photoirradiated from a 400 W high-pressure Hg lamp for 2 h, filtered with suction, and dried in the oven at 353 K.The obtained sample were referred to as Ag(x)photocatalyst, such as Ag(3)CZO, where x was loading amount of Ag in weight calculated from the amount of the start materials. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) of the sample was measured with a Shimadzu Lab X XRD-6000.Diffuse reflectance (DR)

high-pressure Hg lamp gives several bright lines in the spectrum, further detailed discussion about the reaction rates should be avoided here.However, the reaction selectivity can be discussed as follows.Among them, the bare CZO sample produced CO at 2.70 mol h -1 with the highest CO selectivity of 23, and the three samples showed the CO selectivity in the decreasing order, the bare CZO sample the bare SZO sample the bare BZO sample. Since the detected gaseous products were limited to CO, H 2 , and O 2 , the CO selectivity was defined as eq.4, and the ratio of the consumed electrons

high-pressure Hg lamp gives several bright lines in the spectrum, further detailed discussion about the reaction rates should be avoided here.However, the reaction selectivity can be discussed as follows.Among them, the bare CZO sample produced CO at 2.70 mol h -1 with the highest CO selectivity of 23, and the three samples showed the CO selectivity in the decreasing order, the bare CZO sample the bare SZO sample the bare BZO sample. the following possible reasons can be considered.This order was consistent with the decreasing order of the conduction band minimum, i.e., -1.8, -1.6, and -1.2 V, for CZO, SZO, and BZO, respectively as mentioned above, implying that the more negative potential the zirconate photocatalyst has, the more advantageous it is for the CO 2 reduction.However, since all these potentials are largely negative enough to reduce both CO 2 to CO and H to H 2 , it is unclear if these differences of the conduction band
